results.title: Childhood sexual abuse: four case studies
results.creator_credit: Dale McCulley, Cavalcade Productions and MTI Teleprograms
results.brief_description: In a weekend workshop setting, four women relive their experiences of early sexual molestation. Each of the women reveals a uniquely poignant story.

results.title: Child of the Philippines: no time to play
results.creator_credit: Don Whyte, Bryan H. Easte and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Highlights a day in the life of an eleven year old girl who lives in a back country village of the Philippines, and who has to work before and after an eleven hour school day. Explores the problem of children deprived of the basic right to adequate rest and relaxation.

results.title: Child development: infants are individuals
results.creator_credit: Clinic of Child Development and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The material in this film is taken from the Clinic’s photographic records made over a period of 20 years. Each child’s unique individuality asserts itself even in infancy. Bob, Amy, Bess, and Dan at the age of five, we look at their progress from about 12 weeks old to five years.

results.title: Child abuse: emergency management
results.creator_credit: Paul McCollough, S William Hinzman and Producers Service Center
results.brief_description: A child is brought to an hospital emergency room with bruises that indicate possible abuse. This program addresses how to identify whether a crime has been committed, procedures emergency room personnel should follow upon admission of a child and how to approach the parents. The main characters are portrayed by experienced hospital staff and the program emphasises that help can be provided only if the interaction with the parents is handled with skill, support and empathy. Highlights the importance of an interdisciplinary approach to assist the family and child.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul McCollough, S William Hinzman and Producers Service Center

results.title: Child abuse: cradle of violence
results.creator_credit: J. Gary Mitchell, Richard Gebhardt, Jerry Kingsley and Bananza Films
results.brief_description: Through penetrating on-camera interviews with parents, many of them former abusers, the film introduces the grim reality of child abuse. Shows hopeful models for dealing with abuse problems. Also looks at positive parenting, and underlines the need for citizen reporting of suspected abuse so that the abusive family can be helped.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J. Gary Mitchell, Richard Gebhardt, Jerry Kingsley and Bananza Films

results.title: Child's play and the real world
results.creator_credit: James M. Smith, Davidson Films and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: Examines the intimate, colorful and whimsical world of children at play. It dispels the impression that child’s play is merely an entertaining diversion into make-believe and shows how it forms an important part in the development of expression and imagination in children.

results.title: Child's play (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows how mental, social, emotional and physical growth are linked to a child’s form of play and how these forms change as the child grows older. Illustrates how play allows children to work out their feelings and frustrations as well as providing a stage for creative ideas and fantasies.

results.title: Chicks and chickens
results.brief_description: Follows the incubation and hatching of a brood of chicks, and shows a hen as she protects her chicks and teaches them to find food. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Chicken soup with rice
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sendak, Sheldon Riss and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: An excerpt from “Really Rosie”. Features a song about chicken soup with rice as a unifying theme to present an illustrated tour of the months of the year. Adapted from the children’s book, “The Nutshell kids” by Maurice Sendak. Music composed and performed by Carole King. Suitable for lower primary level.
